text: what is up everyone another GameStop update because the volatility won't quit so this is from the 19th of June I want to walk through what the volatility was yesterday what it's looking like today take a walk through the options chain with you guys and then answer a few questions that I got in from a couple of the last videos that I think are great questions and hopefully they will help us look at options more uh in depth and have a better capability to analyze markets with them that's the idea so 19 June volatility was at 20785 after the close right now we have about 13 minutes before the close so Market's not quite closed yet and when I took this screenshot maybe a little less than 10 minutes ago the 20 June front expiration volatility was up to 247 again mine blown the fact that this is kind of scorching up that much is still absolutely wild to me look how far out the implied volatility is starting to increase what I like to do is compare the previous chains and see how far out do I have to go before there's not much change and realistically you have to go out 365 days to the 20 June 25s these are 10365 against 10243 so these went up marginally but there's massive massive massive volatility expansion Within These shorter term expirations again this has gone from 207 to 247 this has gone from 161 to

text: really interesting function here you'll notice on the put side the volatility cracked above 1,300 now it's over 1,500 on the put side now a couple people were talking about this question right here hey something's going on 125 calls IV just exceeded 900 great eyeball unfortunately this doesn't mean as much as you think it might I'll explain to you why when market makers are making markets they have to make qualitative assessments about their risk so when we look at really really far out of the money options we price those typically way more Rich because there's way more risk in holding that position so when we go all the way out here to the 125s that are Bid at a p offered it too we're over 1,000 IV now people are thinking man this means that we got to be going up right it actually doesn't that's that's really not what this means what it means is there's absolutely a perception of risk to the extremes this is what we would call fat tailes and in kind of statistical terms we have a normal distribution curve markets do not represent normal distributions they have what we call skew and curtosis this is not a stats class not going to bore you with it the fact of the matter is is we get extreme moves way more frequently than a normal distribution would project for us so if I give you an example of the really far out

text: skew and curtosis this is not a stats class not going to bore you with it the fact of the matter is is we get extreme moves way more frequently than a normal distribution would project for us so if I give you an example of the really far out of the money puts here notice the implied volatility on the super far out of the money puts 1700 that is because there is a perception of way more risk super far out and this is also one of the biggest problems with buying these really cheap far out ofthe money options is because they're so expensive they are priced so rich for what they are and I know that sounds weird because you're like well dude it's a penny and a half how rich is that on a relative basis Super Rich Mega Rich Ultra Rich cannot be more Rich very rich so what I'm highlighting is this is a pricing functionality of markets the market makers are going to get their pound of flesh to take on what they perceive as risk and that's exactly why you will see this in the far out of the money options now to be clear on a relative basis and something else that you guys may or may not know when we come down here and look at the smile it's exactly what I'm looking at I know that some of you guys think that uh you know it's easier to

text: this kind of normalization where the puts are way more rich and kind of to help maybe prove this point a little bit more let's go to something like apple apple big company moves around but not like a ton and if we take a look at the super far out ofth money puts they're at 2,000 IV it's the same function if we go to the Super far out ofth the money calls in this case it's only 250 why is that well because on a relative basis the market fears the downside way more in carrying this position so it's demanding a massive premium on how they're pricing the Vols in these super far outof the- money options that's one of the the downfalls of using super far outof the money options is on a relative basis they are exceedingly expensive so now as I take a look at the options chain as I typically do with you guys there's a few things I'm seeing the very first thing I'm seeing is take a look at the number of calls traded today however This Time It's Different different especially from yesterday look at how many of those are being entered in at the offer and above 39 this is bullish skew then if I look at the put side and I see 33 of those puts came in at the bid these are selling puts again also bullish skew so it's not easy to say again definitively what

text: me there's enough liquidity in the market right now for market makers to be able to cover their positions that's my guess so as I look at the 20s the 25s we can see we're getting a bit of a rally right now it's up a little over 3 but these are already at a 93 Delta a one Delta so what that tells me is the market makers in these kinds of positions they're already going to be essentially fully edged coming in into the expiration now this is if they're not playing the shell game which they might that's hard to say but from a standardized procedure my assumption would be that as these options are getting further further further in the money that the market makers have plenty of time especially in this scenario with the recent Equity offering to scoop up their protection as needed to fully hedge these positions as they would want that's my guess shell game could be going on again really really difficult to tell we have to wait and see exactly how the price behaves going forward so another wild day another really busy day for GameStop in terms of volatility we see again this crazy expansion so I'm going to be keeping a really close eye on it to see where we go from here as always if you have any questions or anything you want me to take a look at let me know I love looking at this
